label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, September 27, 1945
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, describing the process of being discharged from the Navy, the party that he and Morris are planning to throw for the men they play tennis with at the Beretania Tennis Club, and a dinner they attended at the Wilders. Sidney continues in his letter to discuss business affairs of the dress shop he had purchased in Hawaii and lament that her trip to Acapulco was cancelled.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, describing the process of being discharged from the Navy, the party that he and Morris are planning to throw for the men they play tennis with at the Beretania Tennis Club, and a dinner they attended at the Wilders. Sidney continues in his letter to discuss business affairs of the dress shop he had purchased in Hawaii and lament that her trip to Acapulco was cancelled.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
September 27, 1945
Hello Nimrod,
Whatcha doing killing feathery creatures again when
there has been so much slaughter in the world. Also arent you a
little bit afraid that this might be and probably will be a second
Fort Kaperle.
Certainly is fun talking to you on the phone even though
I c nt hear everything you say. It seems so natural and as you say
"just as if you were in the same room". than I return I am going to
give you a big hug and a kiss and tell that phone to watch me do it
instead of my having to say "I send you all my love" over it.
Getting out of the Navy is quite a hysterical proceeding
out here. I started on the 20th. and am still in it but going strong.
To give youthe idea of the efficiency of it all I will tell you
one thing that happened. I first had to go to Aiea where they
keep my health record. There I was given a physical exam, a very
thorough one wich covered everything. My chest with all the air out
was 89, filled up with air was 41, my waist was 39, my temperature
98, pulse 76, blood pressure 110 and weight 82. The next day
I reported to the sope ration center and was told that I had to take
another physical exam. I explained I had just finished one that took
an hour but that did not make any difference. On this exam my chest
measurements were 35 and 36, my wai st was 59, pulse 90, blood pressure
125 and weight 90. Oh I forgot I also had grown an inch overnight.
After ll thishad been finished we were told that we h d not
brought our pay accounts and of course it was too later for them
to take care of them that day, come back the next afternoon at 2pm.
The next day at two we were told there had been a slight mix up with
our exrays to come back today, today we were told that it was to bad
but the officer who was to sign our pa ers had left, had received
an urgent call , would we return in the morning. However having been
in the Navy for some time I asked "will he be here on Saturday, or
would it be better if we returned Monday. I think that would be safer
the yeoman said. So back e go on Monday. However I think things
are go ng to improve out here as I was to d that Admiral Nimitz has
fired Capt. Lewis the District personnel officer and Captain Kane
at the head of the receiving station for the lousy work they hadve
done in connection with getting men out of the service.
This Sunday we are giving a party to the men who we hav
been playing tennis with at the Beretania Tennis Club. They are
coming with their wives and there will be about thirty people in all.
We are going to have a round robbin tennis tournament first, give
prizes and then a buffet dinner. It should be very good fun I think.
We bought two turkeys that a little jap caterer is g ing to cook 
and we are going to have sald and ice cre m  nd coffee ith it.
These men h ve been the nicest to us since we have come out here. I
h ve never seen their wives but will let you know all about them. 
[End Page 1]
Last Monday night we were asked up to the Wilders
for dinner. They live on the top of Tantalus mountain in an old
brown stained wood house. We had a delicious buffet dinner of
roast beef, creamed potatoes, saldd, ice cream and cake. They
had the liveiliest plates I have ever seen. Persian pottery,
that wonderful blue that you get out there. Pictures of birds on
the plates, and persi an writing on the back. I would love to
have had them.
Jimmy Wilder said that he knew you and Sarah Jane,
but I was unable to discuss you very much with him as he passed
out about nine oclock. I did not have a drink and wondered how in
the world to leave when I got sleepy, but was really stuck because
Admiral Halsey was there and we could not go before he left. He
again started the conversation about the apartments and the two
girls but I walked away. Once is enough. At eleven he arose to
leave and we filed out behind him. There  ere only about twelve
of us altogether, one  dmiral, Carney,was very nice but I was
so sleepy from tennis that I could not carry on any conversation
at all. Mrs [Betty Wilder] was attractive and had a very good
sense of humor. Anyway you c n see I am meeting all the people for
you.
Tat Saunders clothes have not arrived yet. I wish the
would as I would like to see what they look like. I have no
idea what sort of t ings she has sent and therfor cannot say whether
they are the type that will sell out here or not. Jo Jo has not
answered any of my letters, and as a resultthere is a slight mix
up in finances but I will straighten that out on my ret rn. Her
atomic bonb letter never arrived, so I think she either cooled
off or sent it to the wrong address.
I  m terribly sorry that you Aculpulco trip f ll
through, but then neither I nor anyone else expected Ellen to go,
you least of all. If there is one thing that you can be sure of
that is that Ellen Fraser will not go on a trip and especially to
a place more she has not been before. She will go to Watch Hill,
Palm Beach and Long Isl nd, but that isthe limit. I think you
would have had a wonderful time there swimming and playing in the
sun and I am sorry th t you did not go.
 s far as this shooting trip goes I do not want
to go on it. If I come home before the ninth then I think that
we c n do things together that would be more amusing. If I
get home after the ninth then I would suggest that you go on the
shooting trip until my arrival and then we can join up and do all
and everything we please.
So long sweeheart, it wont belong now beofre we
will be together. All my love
[End Page 2]
